In domesticated populations of S. cerevisiae, whole chromosome aneuploidy is known to be very uncommon.

One reason why whole chromosome aneuploidy is uncommon in domesticated populations of S. cerevisiae is that these yeast strains have been selectively bred for specific traits, such as fermentation ability, temperature tolerance, and flavor profile. Over many generations of selective breeding, the frequency of undesirable traits, including whole chromosome aneuploidy, decreases in the population.

Another reason why whole chromosome aneuploidy is uncommon in S. cerevisiae is that these yeast cells undergo meiosis, a type of cell division that results in the production of haploid spores. Meiosis is a highly regulated process that ensures that each spore contains the correct number of chromosomes. Any errors or mutations in meiosis can result in aneuploidy, but in S. cerevisiae, meiosis is tightly controlled and aneuploidy is rare.

In conclusion, the claim "In domesticated populations of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, whole chromosome aneuploidy is very uncommon" is accurate. This is due to the selective breeding of S. cerevisiae and the tight regulation of meiosis in these cells.

The assertion that "Thigh-length graduated compression stockings (GCS) did not reduce deep vein thrombosis in patients admitted to hospital who are immobile because of acute stroke" is based on a study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) in 2018. The study titled "Effect of Thigh-Length Graduated Compression Stockings on Venous Thromboembolism in Patients with Acute Stroke: The GCOMPRESS Randomized Clinical Trial" aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of GCS in reducing the incidence of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in patients with acute stroke.
